pullsbody:
Regarding issue #68

The error generated when trying to open a zlib stream with the gzip module is an [IOError for the missing header](https://hg.python.org/cpython/file/2.7/Lib/gzip.py#l196) (or an [OSError in Python 3.6](https://hg.python.org/cpython/file/3.6/Lib/gzip.py#l411)).

In the interest of future-proofing I've used an EnvironmentError which includes both IOError and OSError.

The existing code this replaces wouldn't have worked even in the even of a zlib.error, as dataStream does not have a decode method.
pull_commit_message: Support zlib compressed symbol files

pullsbody:
Regarding issue #68

The error generated when trying to open a zlib stream with the gzip module is an [IOError for the missing header](https://hg.python.org/cpython/file/2.7/Lib/gzip.py#l196) (or an [OSError in Python 3.6](https://hg.python.org/cpython/file/3.6/Lib/gzip.py#l411)).

In the interest of future-proofing I've used an EnvironmentError which includes both IOError and OSError.

The existing code this replaces wouldn't have worked even in the even of a zlib.error, as dataStream does not have a decode method.
pull_commit_message: Remove now-unused zlib import to satisfy flake8

pulltitle: Document the request and response format
pullsbody:
The README is conspicuously light on documentation about the API requests for symbolication that Snappy exists to serve. This adds documentation for the request and response bodies.

I haven't looked at the Snappy codebase in years, so it's possible I've misrepresented something, but I am intimately familiar with the details of symbol files and whatnot, so I think I've got it right.

I also added a little more info to the introduction that I thought was useful.
pull_commit_message:
Document the request and response format

The README is conspicuously light on documentation about the API requests for symbolication that Snappy exists to serve. This adds documentation for the request and response bodies.

pullsbody:
This PR should fix the intermittent test failures (not including test timeouts). Tests were occasionally failing with errors indicating that the wrong symbols were being returned. It appears that these problems stem from two issues:
- Symbol Files sometimes contain a FUNC and PUBLIC line referencing the same offset
- Some of the test data seems to be wrong

To address this:
- DiskCache will now prioritize PUBLIC symbols over FUNC ones (see Issue #54)
- I wrote a script to verify all test data. I then manually changed incorrect data in cacheMissRequests.json
pull_commit_message: Fixed DiskCache to prioritize PUBLIC symbols over FUNC symbols

pulltitle: Small optimization for symbol parsing code.
pullsbody:
The integer increment operation is surprisingly expensive. lineNum is
incremented for every single line in the sym file. Using enumerate for
line counting makes the code around 20% faster. The readlines()
operation is around 8% slower than iterating over the file object,
but the integer increment avoidance outperforms it.

r? @vdjeric
pull_commit_message:
Small optimization for symbol parsing code.

The integer increment operation is surprisingly expensive. lineNum is
incremented for every single line in the sym file. Using enumerate for
line counting makes the code around 20% faster. The readlines()
operation is around 8% slower than iterating over the file object,
but the integer increment avoidance outperforms it.

pull_commit_message:
Handle ctrl-c on Windows.

select function on Windows does not return on SIGINT interrupt, so ctrl-c
doesn't stop the server. We add a timer to event loop to make select to
return and the server exit on ctrl-c.

pulltitle: Implement on disk symbol file cache.
pullsbody:
Add support for on disk symbol file cache. The cache is done through the pickle module. We maintain a list of the least recently used symbol files. When we reach the quota limit, we start to remove the symbol files until our disk usage fits inside the quota.

r? @vdjeric
pull_commit_message:
Use different log path for each process.

RotatingFileHandler has a bug on Windows which it cannot handle well
file roll over with multiple processes on Windows.

The solution here is to log data in different paths for each process.
The subprocess logs its data in the "subprocess" sub-directory.

pulltitle: Implement on disk symbol file cache.
pullsbody:
Add support for on disk symbol file cache. The cache is done through the pickle module. We maintain a list of the least recently used symbol files. When we reach the quota limit, we start to remove the symbol files until our disk usage fits inside the quota.

r? @vdjeric
pull_commit_message:
Implement on disk symbol file cache.

This commit adds support for on disk symbol file cache. The cache is
done through the pickle module. We maintain a list of the most recently
used symbol files. The MRU is shared between the memory and disk cache.
The first "maxEntries" entries in the MRU corresponds to the memory
cache.

We also refactor the symbol fetching code.

We apply some OOP to symbol fetching here. The concept of a symbol
fetcher object is a interface which will receive a lib and a breakpad id
and return the respective SymbolInfo object, or None if the SymbolInfo
object is not found.

There are currently two fetchers:
* PathFetcher: look for symbol files in local paths.
* URLFetcher: look for symbol files in a remote path.

The symbol file manager constructs a pipeline of fetchers, calling one
by one until either one of them returns a SymbolInfo or all fetchers
are called.

pulltitle: Switch I/O processing to Tornado framework
pullsbody:
Move the I/O processing from "one thread per connection" to Tornado coroutines. This allows us to process multiple connections in a single thread.

The symbolication code has been moved to a separate process so new connections get accepted fast. This is makes better use of multiple cores.

r? @vdjeric
pull_commit_message: Make the default MRU file path platform independent.

pulltitle: Switch I/O processing to Tornado framework
pullsbody:
Move the I/O processing from "one thread per connection" to Tornado coroutines. This allows us to process multiple connections in a single thread.

The symbolication code has been moved to a separate process so new connections get accepted fast. This is makes better use of multiple cores.

r? @vdjeric
pull_commit_message:
Move symbolication processing to a isolated function.

We intend to move the symbolication processing to its own process. This
is the first step to do so by isolating the symbolication code in its
own function.

pulltitle: Switch I/O processing to Tornado framework
pullsbody:
Move the I/O processing from "one thread per connection" to Tornado coroutines. This allows us to process multiple connections in a single thread.

The symbolication code has been moved to a separate process so new connections get accepted fast. This is makes better use of multiple cores.

r? @vdjeric
pull_commit_message:
Move symbolication processing to its own process.

In the efforts to move from the current "one thread per connection"
model to reactor pattern, we process the CPU intensive symbolication
code to its own process, so requests don't get stuck waiting for it to
finish.

Notice the locks in symFileManager are not necessary anymore and we
removed them.

multiprocessing module and Tornado are not good friends, and because of
that we use concurrent.futures.

pulltitle: Switch I/O processing to Tornado framework
pullsbody:
Move the I/O processing from "one thread per connection" to Tornado coroutines. This allows us to process multiple connections in a single thread.

The symbolication code has been moved to a separate process so new connections get accepted fast. This is makes better use of multiple cores.

r? @vdjeric
pull_commit_message:
Switch request processing to async I/O.

Requests are now processed assynchronously, through the Tornado web
framework. The actual job of symbolication is done in a separated
process.

pull_commit_message:
Support environment variables in the configuration file.

It uses the ConfigParser interpolation syntax %(<var>)<type>.

Environment variables are put in the DEFAULT special section, and
calling items() for any section also returns values in DEFAULT. We then
override items() to filter out defaults.

The Linux configuration file is for production, always look for symbols
at S3.

Windows configuration file is for Windows developers. Look for symbols
locally and at remote server.
